query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Several methods for controlling disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms have been studied. A study in Scotland found that fallowing, the practice of leaving cages empty, was associated with lower numbers of sea lice (1026). However, another study in Australia found that fallowing did not reduce mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease (1026). In terms of dietary supplements, one study in Scotland showed that probiotics increased the survival of salmon when they were exposed to bacteria that cause diseases (732). A study in Norway found that a diet containing 28% plant-based protein reduced infections from sea lice by 28%, and the addition of beta-glucans to the diet further decreased the levels of lice infection by 28% (732). The same study also found that the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved the function of the gut (732). The use of cleaner wrasse as a natural control agent has had mixed results in two studies in Ireland (738). One study found that corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments for the control of lice, while another study found that rockcook wrasse were not effective at preventing outbreaks of lice (738).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"disease and sea lice control in Atlantic salmon farms"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "732",
  "action_title": "Use of probiotics and immunostimulants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

A study in Scotland found that fallowing, the practice of leaving cages empty, was associated with lower numbers of sea lice (1026). However, another study in Australia found that fallowing did not reduce mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease (1026). In terms of dietary supplements, one study in Scotland showed that probiotics increased the survival of salmon when they were exposed to bacteria that cause diseases (732). A study in Norway found that a diet containing 28% plant-based protein reduced infections from sea lice by 28%, and the addition of beta-glucans to the diet further decreased the levels of lice infection by 28% (732). The same study also found that the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved the function of the gut (732). The use of cleaner wrasse as a natural control agent has had mixed results in two studies in Ireland (738). One study found that corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments for the control of lice, while another study found that rockcook wrasse were not effective at preventing outbreaks of lice (738)."}

query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?
relevant_summary:
Evidence regarding the impact of substituting fish meal with bacterial protein on Atlantic salmon is varied (918). Two controlled studies in Norway indicated that salmon fed diets with up to 25% bacterial protein had similar growth rates to those on a 100% fish meal diet, but growth rates were lower with a 50% bacterial protein diet (918). Conversely, another Norwegian study found that diets with 18% and 36% bacterial protein resulted in higher growth rates compared to a control group (918).

For plant-based proteins, six studies in Norway, Scotland, and the USA reported decreased growth rates in salmon, while three studies in Norway, Canada, and Scotland found similar growth rates to fish meal diets (924). Four controlled studies in Norway and Scotland noted reduced final body weights in salmon on plant-based diets, whereas two controlled studies in Norway found similar final body weights to those on fish meal diets (924). Additionally, two controlled studies in Norway observed lower feeding efficiency with plant-based diets, although one replicated study in Norway reported an increase (924). The digestibility of feed was found to be lower in two studies with plant protein diets, but two other studies in Scotland and Norway reported similar levels of digestibility to fish meal diets (924).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal for Atlantic salmon growth in Norway"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

Conversely, another Norwegian study found that diets with 18% and 36% bacterial protein resulted in higher growth rates compared to a control group (918).\n\nFor plant-based proteins, six studies in Norway, Scotland, and the USA reported decreased growth rates in salmon, while three studies in Norway, Canada, and Scotland found similar growth rates to fish meal diets (924). query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?
relevant_summary: Two controlled studies in Iceland and Norway investigating disease-causing bacteria reported higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated salmon (733). Additionally, two controlled studies in Australia and Canada found that vaccinated salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease had higher survival rates (733). For salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia, two controlled studies in Norway reported similar findings (733). In relation to breeding for resistance, a replicated, controlled study in Norway observed increased survival levels in salmon from families bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis compared to those bred for low resistance (735). In contrast, a study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used (1026). However, a study in Scotland did record lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system (1026).

{

  "action_title": "Use vaccinations",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups. This was post exposure to the disease-causing bacteria, Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively.
Two controlled studies in Australia and Canadia reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease, post vaccination.
Two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia."
}

query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?
relevant_summary: Several studies in Norway and Scotland have documented the effects of including plant-based proteins in salmon feed. Six studies, four of which were replicated and controlled, in Norway, Scotland, and the USA, indicated that this inclusion led to decreased growth rates in salmon. In contrast, three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada, and Scotland found similar growth rates between salmon fed plant-based diets and those fed fish meal diets (924). Four replicated, controlled studies in Norway and Scotland, three of which were randomized, observed reduced final body weights in salmon on plant-based protein diets compared to those on fish meal-based diets. However, two controlled studies in Norway, one of which was replicated, found no difference in final body weights between the two diet types (924). Regarding feeding efficiency, two replicated, controlled studies in Norway, one of which was randomized, reported lower efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets. Conversely, a replicated study in Norway noted an increase in feeding efficiency with these diets. Two other replicated studies, one of which was controlled, in Canada and Scotland, found similar feeding efficiency across both diet types (924). The digestibility of feed components was found to be lower in salmon on diets containing plant proteins in two replicated, controlled studies when compared to fish meal. On the other hand, two randomized, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway reported similar levels of digestibility for both diet types (924). Furthermore, two studies noted that survival rates and appetite were unaffected by either plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However, the morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomized, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets with plant-based proteins. The condition of the salmon was found to be increased in one randomized, replicated, controlled study, but it was reduced in two other replicated studies (924). In addition to protein, the use of plant-based oils has also been studied. Three replicated studies in Norway, two of which were controlled, found similar growth rates in salmon fed diets with fish oil versus those with vegetable oil. One replicated study in Norway even reported higher growth rates in fish on diets with vegetable oil. Another replicated, controlled study found that salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, depending on the family genetics (926). Two replicated studies in Norway, one of which was controlled, found similar average final body weights between groups of salmon fed both fish oil and vegetable oil diets. Three studies in Norway and Scotland, two of which were replicated and one controlled, showed that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source in their diets. A study in Norway also indicated that the oil source in diets did not affect salmon broodstock fecundity, egg weights, fertility rates, or the weights and development of their fry (926). One replicated Norwegian study observed that salmon on vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to those on a fish oil diet. A replicated, controlled study found high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil. In Scotland, a replicated, controlled study revealed that salmon on vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in their flesh compared to those on diets with fish oil. A replicated study in Norway also found that fresh, frozen, and smoked salmon flesh from fish fed both types of oil-based diets had similar levels of gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity, although pigment concentration was lower in the vegetable oil diets (926).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland"}

query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Several non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms have been studied. Using cleaner wrasse as a natural control agent has shown mixed results, with one study finding them as effective as chemical treatments and another finding them ineffective (738). Altering lighting by using low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting has been reported to lower the numbers of lice on salmon (741). A fallowing system has been recorded to lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages (1026). Additionally, a replicated, controlled study in Norway found that the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein, and that adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% (732). The same study found that probiotics and immunostimulants can increase the survival of salmon exposed to disease-causing bacteria (732).

}

query: How does the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control vary between studies in Scotland and Australia?
relevant_summary: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system [1026]. In contrast, a study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used [1026].

query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?
relevant_summary: One controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative animal proteins [922]. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon that were fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica compared to a control diet containing fishmeal [920]. Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon that were fed diets containing fish meal only or a krill meal substitute [916]. When the krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to salmon fed fish meal, compared to leaving the krill whole [916].

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: In Norway, several studies have explored alternative feed components for Atlantic salmon. For plant-based proteins, the evidence is mixed. While some studies in Norway found that including plant-based proteins decreased growth rates [924], others found similar growth rates to fish meal diets [924]. Similarly, some Norwegian studies showed reduced final body weights with plant-based diets [924], while others found no difference [924]. Feeding efficiency was also varied, with some Norwegian studies showing a decrease [924] and one showing an increase [924]. Two studies in Norway found that the morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed plant-based protein diets [924]. For yeast, one experiment in Norway found no difference in weight for salmon fed diets with Yarrowia lipolytica compared to fishmeal [920]. Regarding genetically modified alternatives, three studies in Norway found no difference in the growth rate of salmon fed diets with GM or non-GM soybeans, and one of these studies also found no differences in the fish's histology [928].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets in Norway"}

query: What are the effects of altering the physical environment of salmon cages, such as their size or lighting, on salmon health in aquaculture?
relevant_summary: A replicated study in Australia indicated that salmon housed in larger cages exhibited lower rates of amoebic gill disease when compared to salmon in smaller cages (742). Additionally, a replicated and controlled study conducted in Norway revealed that salmon exposed to low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting had fewer lice, with the number of lice increasing in correlation with the intensity of the artificial light (741).

query: How do different non-chemical water-based treatments, such as fallowing and freshwater bathing, compare in their reported effectiveness for specific diseases in salmon?
relevant_summary: A study in Scotland reported lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system [1026]. However, another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system was used [1026]. Regarding freshwater bathing, two studies in Australia presented mixed results for reducing amoebic gill disease. One study found a reduction in the number of amoebae on salmon gills that lasted for up to 10 days after bathing, while a replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of both treated and untreated salmon [739].

query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
relevant_summary: One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon that were fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica compared to a control diet containing fishmeal (920). A controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain of Atlantic salmon with and without dietary supplementation of phytase and phosphate (930). A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain of salmon that were fed diets with or without taurine supplementation (930). However, one controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins (922). Another controlled, replicated study in Australia found that fish fed diets supplemented with phytase had greater final weights than those given no supplement (930).
